name: Pakistan
takeaway: Pakistan and China have a deep strategic relationship in the Domains of economy, technology, military and foreign policy.
Pakistan's pivot away from the US has given China huge leverage over Islamabad. Pakistan depends on Chinese support to keep its economy afloat and for military hardware.

In the region, the two country's have a united stance against their common rival, India. On the global stage, the two countries back each other against US policies. The convergence of interests forces the two government's to overlook human rights abuses in their respective countries.
Ties are often secretive and deals are non-transparent; the relationship calls into question the long-term sustainability and benefits to the Pakistani nation.
description-1: In 2023, Pakistan had a GDP per capita of US$1,407 and a total population of 245.67 million people.
description-2: Pakistan established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1951. Pakistan was ranked 152nd in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Partly Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 35/100.

Media.evidence: The main Chinese media outlets are registered and active in Pakistan. However, we could find only one relatively insignifant digital platform that belongs to World Chinese Media.
Media.note: PRC has these media outlets registered and working in Pakistan: China Central Television, China Global Television, China Radio International, Xinhua News Agency, People's Daily, China Economic Daily
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: The China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) Media Forum is active in promoting positive image of PRC in Pakistan
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Over the years, the Chinese embassy and officials have taken Pakistani journalists on tours to cities and provinces in PRC to help paint a positive image of the progress and development there.
Media.note: Pakistan Federation of Union of Journalists
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Capacity building trainings of journalists funded by PRC have taken place in Pakistan, China and virtually.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: China Radio International broadcasts directly into Pakistan in Urdu on MW.        Xinhua has also launched services in about a dozen languages, including Urdu. Both are central to PRC state-media.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There are laws in Pakistan against foreign ownership of broadcast media. In any case, Pakistani media is generally strategically aligned with PRC so there's little value in owning local media, wholly or in part.
Media.note: No evidence found of direct Chinese ownership of media outlets.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: In the last few years,leading Pakistani media houses and outlets—including the Jang Group, the Daily Pakistan, Nawa-i-Waqt, the Associated Press of Pakistan, the Daily Times, Hum News, and Pakistan Today—have signed on to Xinhua’s subscription services. Furthermore, the China Daily has placed its newsfeed prominently on Dawn’s homepage.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: It's not unusual for govt/private stakeholders in CPEC to place media ads promoting the apparent success or cooperation between Pakistan and China, esp on national holidays or to celebrate 10 years of BRI investments in Pakistan.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Because of an ongoing strategic alignment and willingness to work with PRC, overt coercion or pressure isn't observed.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Yes, this is true for media -as well as govt , diplomatic, military and economic ties.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Prominent Pakistani media personalities understand the strategic significance of Pak-China ties. They generally refrain from criticism of the PRC's actions and policies. Few however sometimes try to defend PRC or deny alleged HR abuses.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: All the time. It's been going on for years. Both sides are proud of joint working of parliamentary groups.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan receives all sorts of aid from the PRC. These are often loans, publically disguised as aid.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Training of Pakistani civil servants by the Chinese govt has been going on for several years.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: It's rare or uncommon. No proof of suspected "political" detentions of Pakistanis in China.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Not enough open source information available on this
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Yes, both countries refer to each other as "All-Weather Strategic Cooperative Partners and iron brothers"; they say that the "friendship between the two countries is time-tested and unbreakable."
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan fully supports the PRC's position on Taiwan.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan fully supports the PRC's position on territorial claims in the South China Sea..
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan is an Islamic country. Because of its dependence of China, it avoids publically defending PRC's treatment of muslims in Xinjiang and treats it as its internal matter. In bilateral and multilateral meetings, however, it re-assures PRC of its support.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan openly supports PRC's stance Tibet, in part because of its hostile relations with neighoring India
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Pakistan supports the PRC's assertions on Hong Kong.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: China is advancing collaboration in Pakistan's higher education across the country. It involves thousands of students in many universities. It is therefore significant.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: In Pakistan there are five major Confucius schools operating including the ones in National University of Modern Languages (NUML), University of Sargodha, University of Punjab, University of Agriculture and University of Karachi. Around thirty thousand students in these institutes are learning the Chinese language.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: In the early days of BRI, there was a lot of interest on the Pakistani side to introduce Chinese language classes in schools and colleges. But the enthusiasum appears to have fizzled out due to challenges of governance and capacity issues. Today, some private schools promoting Chinese language learning. But most govt schools do not offer foreign languages. Pakistan currently has one of the highest number of out of school children.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: NUST University in Islamabad is  a member of the "University Alliance of the Silk Road". Examples of Islamabad-based think tanks advocating stronger ties with the PRC include: Pakistan-China Institute and The China Study Center, SDPI.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Pakistan today owes 30 per cent of its foreign debt to China, acc to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). China has invested in virtually every segment of the economy. To safe-guard its investments it must also invest media, research and think-tanks to help create a favorable intellectual capital. So, while there is no open-source evidence available of Chinese funding of think tanks in Pakistan, we have seen mushrooming of China experts in Pakistan who visit China regularly, have great access to Chinese diplomats and they champion PRC's view points and interests in Pakistan. None of this would be possible without the Chinese money. Pakistan is too cash-strapped to fund such activities.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Not much information available on the Pakistani side. However, Chinese sources show that the Chinese Government Friendship Award is one of the overseas High-Level Talent Recruitment Programs.  The recipients of the prizes in 2014, 2021, and 2022 were Professors Atta-ur Rahman, Manzoor Hussain Soomro, and M. Iqbal Choudhary.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Both countries seek to enhance educational cooperation. The Chinese Scholarship Council/Govt. of China offers Pakistani scholars opportunities to study and conduct research in Chinese Universities. On the Pakistani side, the Higher Education Commission of Govt. of Pakistan nominates individuals for these scholarships.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Unlikely, because Pakistani schools do not really focus much on East Asian history.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Discussion over these issues is avoided because the country as a whole is increasingly dependent on China and doesn't want to upset Beijing. Pro-China experts tend to whitewash HR abuses in China. However, most Pakistanis would be forgiven for not knowing much about PRC's stance on Taiwan and Hong Kong. Islamist and right-wing institutions like to champion the cause of Muslims the world over, except in China.
Academia.note: These are generally treated as China's internal matters, esp in govt universities and state-controlled private media. However of late, there seems to be a planned effort by PRC to enlist Pakistani writers and scholars to paint Xinjiang in a positive light.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Pakistan has four provinces. They have constitutional autonomy over health, education, policing, mineral wealth, energy, etc. These provincial governments have routinely wooed Chinese govt/investors and signed several bilateral deals.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Pakistan has several sister cities and provinces with many countries, including China.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Pakistan and China have a patron-client relationship. As a creditor and a financier, China helps keep Pakistani economy afloat. So while it may not directly fund many "official" trips, the budget is indirectly financed by PRC.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Yes, local mayors and community leaders meet Chinese officials in Pakistan and also visit them in China.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Yes, it's a part of ongoing strategic partnership between the two countries.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: No significant allegations or reporting on Chinese campaign donations available. It is conceivable, given PRC's deep financial stakes, but there seems to be little evidence so far
Domestic Politics.note: Most major parties favour deeper engagement with China anyway. There are allegations that they recive kick-backs on major projects. But no major accusation of campaign financing. Pakistan's electoral laws bar candidates from receiving state funding of foreign governments.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: No evidence or need in Pakistan, where overall opinion is largely pro-PRC
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: China wields a behind the scenes influence in Pakistan's domestic politics. It's officials generally refrain from publically commenting on Pakistan's domestic politics.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: The most popular politician, Imran Khan, as PM repeatedly idealised China's tough policies to root out corruption. Other leaders, like Sharif, also tend to admire Chinese centralised development model. Still others believe that the Chinese authoritarianism is ill-suited for Pakistan.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: In the early days of BRI investments ten years ago, questions or criticism was actively discouraged. Since then, the atmosphere has changed. These days, some criticism is tolerated in the media amidst the overall positive sentiment towards China. This observation is based on personal experience having worked in the Pakistan media for 25+ years.
Domestic Politics.note: Political parties and govt institutions recognise Pakistan's dependency on China for economic bail out and military hardware. They therefore avoid public criticism of China.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: China is Pakistan's 2nd biggest trading partner after the US
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: China and Chinese commercial banks held about 30% of Pakistan's total external debt of about $100 billion
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: PRC-linked entities have invested heavily in copper and gold mines in Balochistan province & Coal in the desert region of Thar in Sindh province.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: PRC has multibillion dollar investment in Pakistan's Gwader Port, power plants, coal mines, copper and gold extraction, etc.
Economy.note: Chinese trade and industrial concerns are operating throughout the country, with joint and wholly-owned interests in textile factories, cement plants, power producers, steel mills, housing projects and telecommunication concerns, the Pakistan-China Joint Chamber of Commerce and Industry’s (PCJCCI) website shows.\nExamples: Gwadar Sea Port and Thar Coal power project
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: Pakistan is an approved member of AIIB's Second Resilient Institutions for Sustainable Economy (RISE-II) Development Policy Financing
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: Major Pakistani businesses have partnered with PRC entities for Belt and Road projects. Board of Investment (Prime Minister’s Office) (BOI) is a member of the Belt & Road Industrial and Commercial Alliance (BRICA). The Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce & Industry (FPCCI)  is part of the Belt and Road Global Forum.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: Both countries interested in putting in place low cost, high vitality, clearing arrangements for financial transactions
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: No publically avialable evidence to suggest coercion.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: Yes, in Dec 2023, both govts agreed to revise their existing free trade agreement to provide trade finance in yuan and offer loans for relocation of Chinese firms in Pakistan.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: Yes, special economic zones are an important aspect of Phase 2 of CPEC.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: China rolled over $2 bln loan to Pakistan in 2023 (different from debt restructuring); It is expected to make the request again in 2024 due to its liquidity crisis
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: China has emerged as one of main players in Pakistan’s Telecom Sector: China Mobiles’ Zong 4G (CMPAK) is one of the main players in Pakistan’s telecom sector
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Huawei, Haier and Zong are among major Chinese investment companies in Pakistan's telecom sector.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan is heavily reliant on Chinese technology for its telecom infrastructure upgrades. Chinese firm is laying 16,000-km-long fibre-optic cable.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan relies and trusts China more than the US for its hi-tech needs.  security system for the Karot Hydropower Station in Pakistan—one of the projects of the China–Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan and China have an ongoing cooperation in installation of CCTV cameras (Smart Cities), surveillance technology, biometrics, etc.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan is already home to a number of smart city projects. In Lahore, the government is working on a smart traffic management system that uses sensors and artificial intelligence to monitor traffic flow and reduce congestion. In Karachi, a smart card system is being used to improve public transportation. And in Islamabad, a smart grid project is underway to improve the city’s electricity supply.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: The two countries plan to transform optical fiber cable network into global digital gateway. It involves expanding existing optical fiber cable infrastructure to global marine cables to facilitate digital access to regions spanning the Middle East, Central Asia, China, and Europe.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan’s e-commerce industry is still in its infancy. Experts say it has potential and interest from PRC firms to attract financing. Last year, the two countries agreed on a project fostering collaboration between 200 startup enterprises across various IT sectors, including the Internet of Things (IoT), cloud technology and others.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: During the last few years, events have been held and opportunities explored for collaboration in AI, blockchain, cloud computing and big data.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: In Oct 2023, Pakistan officially joined China’s International Lunar Research Station, the China National Space Administration. Pakistan signed a series of space exploration agreements with China in 2019, which included China helping to train and launch Pakistani astronauts.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Pakistan was the first foreign country to use China based GPS system made by Beidou Satellite System. Beidou, or Compass, has also set up network in Pakistan.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: PRC affliated groups usually do not lobby on this issues in Pakistan. Despite lacking an association such as the Association for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification of China, there are small and insignificant Chinese organizations in Pakistan that consistently support and mirror the PRC's position on matters pertaining to Taiwan, Hong Kong, Tibet, and Xinjiang.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: United World Chinese Association isn't well known or active in Pakistan.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Chinese diaspora usually keep a low public profile due to security threats. Still, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan has launched a series of activities to celebrate the “Happy Chinese New Year-2024 as Year of the Dragon”.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence:
"Two countries have signed the ""Belt and Road"" News Exchange and Cooperation Agreement. Pakistan Academy of Letters is a member of the Literary Network of the Belt and Road which hosted by China Writers Association.
Additionally, the group co-organized the Pakistan-China Literary Forum in collaboration with the China Writers Association, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan, and the Pakistani Embassy in China. All-China Women's Federation and All Pakistan Women's Association have held China-Pakistan Women's Forum."
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Chinese organizations build “caring homes” for poor children in Pakistan.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Chinese entertainment content isn't really popular in Pakistan, perhaps due to the language or cultural barriers. Efforts were made for collaboration in film and tv drama a few years ago, but it wasn't entirely successful.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Except for TikTok, Chinese messaging Apps like WeChat aren't really popular in Pakistan. TikTok is third on the appfigures and Snapchat ranks fifth. And Snapchat on the Sensor Tower's fifth floor.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Public events relatively restricted due to security threats. Over the last few years, these events were held virtually/ online or inside the embassy security.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: Not much open source material available on this
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence:
Pakistan generally have a favourable view of China and its govt because of state to state relations. An exception to this may be the sparsely populated south-western province of Balochistan, where separatists denounce PRC's investment in infrastructure and mining projects. 
Pakistanis generally do not feel culturally close to China. The relationship is more political, economic and transactional.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: PRC is Pakistan's main defense supplier, from fighetr jets to missiles and other military hardware. The Chinese police also provide training and technical facilities including modern weapons to police in Pakistani provinces.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: China and Pakistan have ongoing cooperation on security and counter-terrorism. It has been expanded to include Afghanistan and Iran. Pakistan is a member of SCO and backs China's proposed Global Security Initiative (GSI)
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Pakistan and China's defense ties are deep and they go back decades. The two countries cooperate in the production and transfer of tanks, missiles, aircrafts and other military equipment.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Reports of China's interest in developing a base in the port city of Gwadar are not new. Ties between the two militaries stretch back years, with their navies and air forces holding bilateral exercises in each other's territory.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: The Chinese Peoples Liberation Army (PLA) dispatched emergency humanitarian supplies to flood-hit Pakistan in 2022. During COVID-19, PLA provided vaccines to Pakistan Army. Pakistan also provides disaster relief to China.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Not enough publically information available on this.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Pakistan and China have a deep military to military cooperation. They regularly hold joint exercises and drills. Pakistan law enforcement officers have been trained by the PRC.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Highest level meetings between PLA and Pakistan's civil-military leaders are not uncommon.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Not enough info available to substantiate this. The army effectively leads Pakistan's strategic ties with PRC. The deals and negotiations are often secretive and not subject to parliamentary or media scrutiny. Pakistani generals are known to have enriched themselves. Given the strategic alliance and growing dependence on China, it would not be surprising if serving and retired commanders have received personal benefits and rewards from the PRC or its entities. However, in the absence of proof, this would be a speculation.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Military.evidence: Pakistan and China call themselves ALL-weather strategic allies and routinely reiterate their "iron-clad" friendly ties.
Military.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Pakistan approved extradition treaty with China in 2018
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Pakistan and China enjoy a robust relationship in defence and security areas. They have a long running cooperation against terrorism.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: There were some incidents of Chinese nationals involved in bank fraud and alleged trafficking of women, but no reported presence of high level orginased crime (TRIAD) in Pakistran.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Not really, given the tight state to state relations between the two sides.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Seminars and exchange visists have taken place to enhance cooperation in judicial and legal matters. But it doesn't seem signifant because Pakistani criminal justice system is derived from the British and Islamic law.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: On the contrary, separatist militant groups have attacked and killed Chinese and Pakistani individuals working on BRI projects.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Pakistan and China cooperate on cyber security. Threats, disinfo and hacking threats are reported to have come from India or groups in Europe funded by the Indian govt.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: This has not been a concern in Pakistan.
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Every now and then, Pakistani police are reported to have cracked down on Uyghurs at risk for deportation
Law Enforcement.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Over the last decade or so, Pakistan has deported Uyghur Muslims. But hardly any political or Islamic party has openly criticised or denounced the practice.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Pakistan looks to China for CCTV monitoring, Smart Cities, internet monitoring and control -all in the name of safety and security.
